title: How to Make Low‐Carb Cocktails

steps.headline: Try a classic low-carb mojito.
steps.description: Mojitos are great refreshing cocktails that don't rely on a lot of mixers or sweeteners. To make a classic mojito that's low in carbs, smash 1 ounce of lime juice or about 4-6 lime wedges, 8 mint leaves and 1 tablespoon of zero-calorie sweetener in the bottom of a tall glass. Add ice to the glass and pour in 1 1/2 ounces of white rum. Fill the glass with club soda or seltzer water and stir before serving.For a variation on a low-carb mojito, you can use diet lemon-lime soda instead of the club soda and zero-calorie sweetener.

steps.headline: Mix up a low-carb margarita.
steps.description: Classic margaritas usually contain simple syrup or triple sec, which are sugary additions. To cut back on the carbs, combine 2 ounces of tequila, 1 ounce of lime juice, and 1 tablespoon of zero-calorie sweetener or orange extract in a cocktail shaker with ice. Shake it till it's cold, then pour the mixture through a fine strainer into a margarita glass.

steps.headline: Make a low-carb gin and tonic.
steps.description:
You may think that since gin and tonics don't contain much mixer or sugars, they'd be low in carbs. Unfortunately, most tonic water is high in carbohydrates and sugar. To make a low-carb version, use a sugar-free tonic water or a no-carb tonic water. Low-carb tonics are made with natural sweeteners like agave. You'll need to mix together:1 1/2 ounces of gin
4 to 6 ounces of no-sugar or low-carb tonic water
Ice to mix

steps.headline: Try a whiskey and diet cola.
steps.description: A traditional whiskey and cola runs high in carbohydrates. For a simple replacement that's lower in calories, mix 1 shot (1.5 ounces) of whiskey with about 4 1/2 ounces of diet cola. Pour the drink over ice and enjoy it immediately.An even better replacement for the high carb whiskey and cola is just whiskey on the rocks. This cuts out all of the sugar that comes with the soda or diet cola.

steps.headline: Drink a sportsman cocktail.
steps.description: A sportsman cocktail, also known as a "Skinny Bitch," is the closest you can get to a no-carb drink! Put a couple of ice cubes in a highball glass, then pour in 1 1/2 ounces of vodka and 4 1/2 ounces of club soda. Squeeze a lime wedge into the drink, stir it, and enjoy!

steps.headline: Use diet sodas.
steps.description: Most of the carbohydrates in cocktails comes from the sweetener in the drink which could mean the soda, juice, or simple syrup that flavors the cocktail. Try to cut out as much of the sugar as possible or use a diet soda replacement. For example, instead of drinking a Moscow Mule with ginger beer, vodka, and lime, you could mix diet ginger soda with vodka and a little lime.

steps.headline: Substitute tonic water for soda water.
steps.description: You may think that a classic cocktail (like a gin and tonic) that relies on tonic water would be low in calories, but most tonic waters are high in carbs. Swap out tonic water in any cocktail for soda water like seltzer water or club soda which are calorie free. You may be able to purchase low-calorie tonic water in specialty stores.

steps.headline: Drink distilled spirits.
steps.description: Distilled spirits contain calories, but no carbs. If you enjoy the taste, consider drinking the distilled spirits without any mixers. You can enjoy gin, tequila, vodka, rum, or whiskey. You should also keep these spirits in mind when mixing your own low-calorie cocktails at home.Avoid flavored liqueurs and fortified alcohol which are all higher in carbohydrates.

steps.headline: Ask for tea.
steps.description: Most restaurants and bars offer unsweetened iced tea. You can order a glass of iced tea and a shot of your favorite distilled spirit (gin, tequila, rum, vodka, or whiskey). If you choose an unsweetened iced tea, this will make a great low-calorie cocktail.For a little extra flavor, ask for a few lemon wedges to squeeze into the drink.

steps.headline: Avoid juice or cream-based cocktails.
steps.description: Cream or juice-based cocktails like a white Russian, mudslide, or margarita are high in calories because of the cocktail base, not the alcohol. Try to avoid cocktails that are mainly mixed with cream or juice since these are high in sugar and carbohydrates. You should also avoid cocktails with garnishes that are high in carbohydrates, like additional fruit or whipped cream.
